event.comment: My slides became quite popular and were featured in the homepages of SlideShare, reddit, YCombinator Hacker News and many other websites. Christian Heilmann praised it on <a href="

event.name: MediaCampAthens

project.name: Color.js
project.description: A color space agnostic color conversion and manipulation library, developed jointly with [Chris Lilley](https://svgees.us). Used to generate figures and examples for several CSS specifications and influenced the [Color API](https://github.com/wicg/color-api)

project.name: md-block
project.description: A lightweight HTML custom element for Markdown that uses the popular [marked](https://marked.js.org/) library.

project.name: Parsel
project.description: A tiny, permissive CSS selector parser and specificity calculator.

project.name: MaVoice
project.description: A free app to vote on repo issues for any repo, that uses GitHub Issues under the hood. Made with Mavo.

project.name: LCH Color Picker
project.description: A color picker to explore LCH colors that are now being added to CSS. Made with Mavo.

project.name: Issue closing stats
project.description: An app to display issue closing stats for any repo. Made with Mavo.

project.name: Mavo
project.description:
Mavo helps you turn your static HTML into reactive web applications without a single line of programming code and no server backend. 
Developed in the Haystack Group at MIT CSAIL and led by Lea Verou.

**Impact:** Led to the publication of [several research papers](https://lea.verou.me/publications/#research)

project.name: Bliss
project.description: Want to use Vanilla JS but find native APIs a bit unwieldy? Bliss is for you.

project.name: Stretchy
project.description: Form element autosizing, the way it should be.

project.name: Conic gradient polyfill
project.description:
A polyfill for CSS conical gradients.

**Impact:** [Encouraged browsers to implement CSS conic gradients](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=502970). Because the polyfill also implemented the double color stop position syntax, [browsers implemented that alongside](https://chromestatus.com/feature/5712111258828800), just so the examples in the polyfill page work correctly.

project.name: Multirange
project.description:
A tiny polyfill for HTML5 multi-handle sliders.

**Impact:** Was apparently used so much that its custom properties appeared in [Web Almanac's analysis of the top 1000 custom property names](https://almanac.httparchive.org/en/2020/css#naming)

project.name: Awesomplete
project.description: Ultra lightweight, customizable, simple autocomplete widget with zero dependencies. Featured on Github’s weekly Github Explore newsletter when it launched.

project.name: DPI love
project.description: More than you probably wanted to know about screen DPI.

project.name: corner-shape preview
project.description: Preview the corner-shape property before it’s implemented in browsers, through SVG.

project.name: Contrast Ratio
project.description:
Contrast Ratio is a modern tool for testing whether a combination of colors passes WCAG 2.0. It accepts any CSS color the browser accepts, including semi-transparent colors, color keywords, HSL(A) colors and the like. You can also share color combinations with others by just sharing the current URL.

**Impact:** It has become one of the most popular contrast checkers on the Web, and [has been featured in several books](https://www.google.com/search?q=%22contrast-ratio.com%22+OR+%22leaverou.github.io%2Fcontrast-ratio%22&tbm=bks) and talks.

project.name: Prism
project.description:
A lightweight, extensible syntax highlighter, built with modern web standards in mind. 

**Impact:** Pretty much my most successful project, used in a number of high profile websites like [Mozilla Developer Network](https://developer.mozilla.org/), Google’s [web.dev](https://web.dev/), [Sitepoint](https://www.sitepoint.com/), [Smashing Magazine](http://smashingmagazine.com), [A List Apart](http://alistapart.com), [CSS Tricks](http://css-tricks.com) and many others. Over [8 million downloads weekly on npm](https://www.npmjs.com/package/prismjs).

project.name: The CSS3 Test
project.description:
High coverage testsuite for the most stable CSS modules. 50,000 unique visitors on its launch. 

**Impact:** Motivated browser vendors such as [Mozilla](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=913153) or [WebKit](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=79073) to support more CSS3 features to increase their scores on it.

project.name: Dabblet
project.description:
An interactive CSS playground. Was quite successful for a few years, with thousands of visitors every day. Several popular industry media like [Wired.com’s WebMonkey](http://www.webmonkey.com/2011/12/dabblet-an-interactive-css-playground-in-your-browser/), [CSS-Tricks](http://css-tricks.com/dabblet/), [Smashing Magazine](http://www.smashingmagazine.com/smashing-newsletter-issue-50/) and others wrote about Dabblet’s release. During its first month, it received more than 65,000 unique visitors, 15,000 of which during its first two days.

**Impact:** Pioneered using Github Gists as a storage backend, and its inline previewers for various value types predate similar features in today's editors.

project.name: Animatable
project.description: A CSS transitions gallery that shows what's possible with even the most basic of transitions: one property, two values.

project.name: -prefix-free
project.description: -prefix-free was a library that allowed authors to write standard, prefix-less CSS and have the necessary prefixes added on runtime. It used feature detection for almost everything instead of hardcoded lists, allowing it to remain extremely lightweight and always up-to-date regardless of its version. Was gradually abandoned as browsers moved away from vendor prefixes, since the problem it was solving all but disappeared.

project.name: cubic-bezier.com
project.description:
A tool that helps you work with the easing functions of CSS3 transitions & animations and share them with others.

**Impact:** It has been featured on several [books](https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22cubic-bezier.com%22) and talks. Its code was at some point even [included in the Firefox browser](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2014/07/event-listeners-popup-media-sidebar-cubic-bezier-editor-more-firefox-developer-tools-episode-33/) and [Adobe's Brackets editor](https://twitter.com/brackets/status/400678387045642241)

project.name: CSS Colors
project.description: A tool that helps you convert between the different CSS-accepted color formats (including name keywords) as well as share them with others.

project.name: CSS3 patterns gallery
project.description:
An interactive gallery that demonstrated what's possible with just CSS gradients. It also allows you to edit the code, to experiment with gradients yourself.

**Impact:** The gallery and the corresponding blog posts started the — now widespread — practice of using hard stops in CSS gradients to easily create background patterns. It has been [featured in a number of books](https://www.google.com/search?q=%22css3patterns%22&tbm=bks), talks, workshops. It was used by Opera Software to fine-tune their CSS gradients implementation.

project.name: Chainvas
project.description: Chainvas is a tiny generic chaining library that can make any API's methods chainable (like jQuery). Official plugins for the DOM and the Canvas API included.

project.name: CSS gradients please!
project.description: A tool that converts the standard gradient syntax to -webkit-gradient and adds the rest of the prefixes

project.name: CSS3 structural pseudo-class selector tester
project.description: A tool that helps you learn how the :nth-whatever() CSS3 pseudo-classes work.

project.name: HTML5 <progress> polyfill
project.description: A very thorough (perhaps too thorough) polyfill for the HTML5 <progress> element.

project.name: StronglyTyped
project.description: A library for constants and strongly typed variables in JavaScript.

project.name: Incrementable
project.description: A script that enables incrementing/decrementing multiple numeric values in textfields with the keyboard arrow keys.

project.name: Inspire.js
project.description: My slide deck framework, built exclusively with open web technologies. Includes plugins for editable CSS regions, syntax hightlighting and more. Originally released under the name CSSS in 2010, rewritten in 2018 and renamed to Inspire.js

project.name: rgba.php
project.description: A server-side script that automatically generates semi-transparent PNGs to be used as fallbacks for RGBA colors.

publication.title: CSS Secrets
publication.comment:
* Sold over 20,000 copies
* Translated into **8 languages** ([German](http://www.dpunkt.de/buecher/12468/9783960090250-css-secrets.html), [Polish](http://helion.pl/ksiazki/css-bez-tajemnic-47-sekretow-kreatywnego-projektanta-lea-verou,scss47.htm), [Russian](https://www.piter.com/collection/all/product/sekrety-css-idealnye-resheniya-ezhednevnyh-zadach), [Japanese](https://www.amazon.co.jp/CSSシークレット-_47のテクニックでCSSを自在に操る-Lea-Verou/dp/4873117666/), [Simplified Chinese](https://www.amazon.cn/CSS揭秘-希-韦鲁/dp/B01MDS2JQ0/), [Traditional Chinese](http://books.gotop.com.tw/v_A447), [Korean](http://www.kyobobook.co.kr/product/detailViewKor.laf?ejkGb=KOR&barcode=9788965401421), [Bulgarian](https://www.zest-press.com/taynite-na-css.html))
* Recommended as the best CSS book by the [Chicago Tribune](https://www.chicagotribune.com/consumer-reviews/sns-bestreviews-electronics-the-best-css-book-20200701-kda2pyikobda5o3c4ivi4wzfui-story.html) and as "Best of the Best" in CSS books by [BestReviews](https://bestreviews.com/best-css-books) (used by Amazon for Editorial Recommendations).
* Average of **4.6/5** on [Amazon](http://www.amazon.com/CSS-Secrets-Solutions-Everyday-Problems/dp/1449372635/), 182 reviews.
* Was consistently in the [top 10 Amazon bestsellers on CSS](http://www.amazon.com/gp/bestsellers/books/379357011/ref=pd_zg_hrsr_b_1_5_last) and the [top 30 on User Experience & Usability](http://www.amazon.com/gp/bestsellers/books/4033/ref=pd_zg_hrsr_b_2_4_last), for the first year since its publication date.
* [Over 1000 endorsements on Twitter](https://twitter.com/csssecretsbook)
